Urgent MRI of the brainstem, brain, cervical cord and orbits is needed to confirm localisation, differentiate demyelination from infarct, haemorrhage or tumour, and guide acute therapy. CSF studies, visual evoked potentials and serum antibody testing help confirm multiple sclerosis or neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder, while routine blood tests, autoimmune and infectious screens exclude important mimics. Vascular imaging and basic cardiac work-up are required if imaging suggests ischaemia, and chest imaging is appropriate in view of cough and to screen for sarcoidosis or infection.
